facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 126 of 1966 arising from the judgment and order dated November 29 and December 2, 1963 of the Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Application No. 641 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated November 29, and December 2, 1963 of the Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Application No. 641 of 1962. R. Chaudhuri, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellants are dealers registered under the Bombay Sales Tax Act 1946 carrying on business in art silk, cotton and hand loom cloth.

anchor.surface_text: The facts material for the purpose of deciding the question formulated above, are these The appellants are dealers registered tinder the Act carrying on business in art silk, companyton and hand loom cloth.

facts.text: During January 26, 1950 to March 31, 1950, appellants effected various sales outside the State of Bombay protected by Art. 286(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: During the period January 26, 1950 to March 31, 1950, the appellants effected various sales outside the State of Bombay. As those sales were protected by Art. 286 1  a  of the Constitution, they were outside the reach of the Act.

facts.text: Sales tax officer assessed turnover relating to sales outside Bombay from Jan 26 to Mar 31, 1950 and levied tax of Rs. 4,494/3/9.

anchor.surface_text: But yet the sales tax officer assessed the turnover relating to those sales. The tax levied in respect of that turnover was Rs. 4,494/3/9.

facts.text: In appeal, Assistant Collector of sales tax affirmed the order of sales tax officer.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal, the order of the sales tax officer was affirmed by the Assistant Collector of sales,tax.

facts.text: Additional Collector of sales tax in revision revised the levy and ordered refund of Rs. 2,238/0/6 which was paid to assessees.

anchor.surface_text: But the Additional Collector of sales tax in revision revised the levy to some extent and, ordered a refund of Rs. 2,238/0/6. That amount was paid to the assessees.

facts.text: Appellants filed revision to Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Not being satisfied with the order of the Additional Collector of sales tax, the appellants took up the matter in revision to the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: On May 17, 1958, Additional Collector informed appellants by letter that unless proof of refund to purchasers furnished within 3 months, amount liable to forfeiture under s.12A(4).

anchor.surface_text: But even before they moved the Tribunal in revision, the Additional Collector of sales tax by his letter dated May 17, 1958, informed the appellants that unless they furnished to the sales tax officer proof of their having refunded the amount paid to them in pursuance of his order to the purchasers within a period of three months from the date of that numberice, the same would be liable to be forfeited under s. 12A 4

facts.text: Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal on November 26, 1958 allowed appellants' claim in full and directed refund of additional Rs. 2,256/2/6.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal by its order dated November 26, 1958, allowed the claim of the appellants in full and directed the refund of an addi- tional sum of Rs. 2,256/2/6.

facts.text: During April 1, 1950 to March 31, 1951, appellants effected sales outside Bombay, turnover taxed by STO at Rs. 23,806/3/6.

anchor.surface_text: During the period April 1, 1950 to March 31, 1951 the appel- lants effected various sales outside the State of Bombay. The turn, over relating to those sales was also brought to tax by the sales tax officer and in that companynection a tax of Rs. 23,806/3/6 was levied on the appellants.

facts.text: Assistant Collector in appeal allowed partial claim, ordered refund Rs. 12,154/15/- but informed forfeiture if not refunded to purchasers.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal, the Assistant Collector of sale tax allowed the appellants claim in part and ordered a refund or. Rs. 12,154/15/- but at the same time he informed them that that amount would be forfeited to the State Government if number refunded to the purchasers from whom the same had been companylected.

facts.text: Additional Collector on November 1, 1958 ordered additional refund Rs. 3,588/1/9 but sales tax officer did not give effect.

anchor.surface_text: That officer by his order dated November 1, 1958 granted further relief by ordering refund of an additional sum of Rs. 3,588/1/9. But the sales tax officer did number give effect to that order.

facts.text: Tribunal allowed appellants' claim in full for 1950-51 period.

anchor.surface_text: As the Additional Collector did number accept the appellants claim in full, they went up in revision to the Tribunal. The Tribunal allowed their claim in full.

facts.text: Revenue's reference to High Court was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The Revenue took up the matter in reference to the High Court but that reference was rejected.

facts.text: Appellants entitled to refund of Rs. 23,806/3/6 for April 1, 1950 to March 31, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: From the foregoing it is seen that in respect of the period April 1, 1950 to March 31, 1951- the appellants are entitled to get a refund of Rs. 23,806/3/6.

facts.text: Sales tax officer did not pay the amounts ordered to be refunded and threatened forfeiture under s.12A(4).

anchor.surface_text: Despite the aforementioned orders, the sales tax officer did number pay the amounts ordered to be refunded. On the other hand, he threatened to take steps to forfeit the same by having recourse to s. 12A 4 .

facts.text: On June 27, 1962, sales tax officer called upon assessees to appear on July 2, 1962 with particulars of tax collected from purchasers in other states 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: On June 27, 1962, the sales tax officer called upon the assessees to remain present in their office on July 2, 1962 with particulars of the amount companylected by them by way of sales tax from the purchasers in other States during the period January 26, 1950 to March 31, 1951.

facts.text: Appellants filed Special Civil Application No. 641 of 1962 in Gujarat High Court under Art. 226 praying for compliance with refund orders and restraint from action under s.12A(4).

anchor.surface_text: At that stage, the appellants approached the High Court of Gujarat by special civil application No. 641 of 1962 under Art. 226 of the Constitution. In that application, they prayed for several reliefs, the most important of which was to direct the respondents to companyply with the orders of refund and to refrain from taking any action against them under s. 12A 4 .

facts.text: Gujarat High Court dismissed the special civil application.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed that application. Hence. this appeal.

facts.text: Bombay Sales Tax Act 1946 came into force on March 8, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The Act provides for the levy of tax on the sale of goods in the then State of Bombay. It came into force on March 8, 1946.

facts.text: Appellants are registered dealers under sections 8 and 8A of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 8 and s. 8 a  of the Act provide for the registration of dealers. As mentioned earlier the appellants are registered dealers.

facts.text: Sales outside Bombay were not exigible to tax under Art. 286(1)(a) as it stood at relevant time.

anchor.surface_text: In view of Art. 286 1  a  of the Constitution as it stood at the relevant time, the appellants sales outside the State of Bombay were number exigible to tax.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the application leading to this appeal by certificate.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed that application. Hence. this appeal.
companystitutional validity of S. 12A 4  of the Bombay Sales Tax 1946, to be hereinafter referred to as the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Provides for automatic forfeiture of amounts collected by way of tax in excess or in contravention without any adjudication, enquiry or procedure; held void as violative of Art. 19(1)(f).
concepts.unlisted_description: Forfeiture of tax amounts collected in contravention of ss.12A(1),(2) or in excess.

anchor.surface_text: As in our judgment that provision is void, the same being violative of Art. 19 1  f  of the Constitution,

concepts.interpretation: Guarantees freedom to hold property; impugned provision infringes it by arbitrary forfeiture without procedure; not saved by reasonable restrictions under Art.19(5) due to lack of procedural safeguards.

issues.text: the constitutional validity of S. 12A(4) of the Bombay Sales Tax Act 1946

anchor.surface_text: companystitutional validity of S. 12A 4  of the Bombay Sales Tax 1946, to be hereinafter referred to as the Act.

issues.text: whether it [the impugned provision] is violative of Art. 19(1)(f) which guarantees the freedom to hold property

anchor.surface_text: But the question is whether it is violative of Art. 19 1  f  which guarantees the freedom to hold property. Prima facie the appellants are entitled to get the amount ordered to be refunded to them.

issues.text: whether the power conferred under S. 12A(4) is unguided, uncanalised and uncontrolled

anchor.surface_text: On a reasonable interpretation of the impugned provision, we have no doubt that the power conferred under S. 12A 4  is unguided, uncanalised and uncontrolled. It is an arbitrary power.

issues.text: whether the restrictions imposed by the legislative enactment upon a fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 19(1) are reasonable within the meaning of Art. 19(5)

anchor.surface_text: whether the restrictions imposed by a. legislative enactment upon a fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 19 1  are reasonable within the meaning of Art. 19 5

issues.text: whether from the language of the impugned provision it is possible to hold that it is a penal provision

anchor.surface_text: We shall not go into the question whether from the language of the impugned provision it is possible to hold that it is a penal provision. For our present purpose we shall assume it to be so.

issues.text: scope of the expression 'collects any amount by way of tax' in s. 12A(4)

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of deciding the point in issue it is not necessary to find out the scope of the expression collects any amount by way of tax in s. 12A 4 .

arguments.claim: Section 12A(4) is a penal provision providing for imposition of penalty for contravention of s.12A(1) and (2), and power to enact it is incidental to power to tax sales under Entry 54 List II.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Revenue s. 12A 4  is a penal provision and it provides for the imposition of penalty on those who companytravene s. 12A 1  and  2 . It was said on its behalf that power to enact such a provision is incidental to the power to tax sales. In support of that companytention reliance was placed on the decision of the Gujarat High Court in Ram Gopal v. Sales Tax Officer, Surat and Another 1 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: , such a case also companyes within the scope of s. 12A 4 . Yet that s

arguments.court_reasoning: The said decision cannot be sustained.

arguments.claim: Impugned provision is not a taxation measure and cannot be ancillary or incidental to taxing power under Entry 54 List II as it targets amounts not exigible as tax.

anchor.surface_text: It was number companytended number companyld it have been companytended that the impugned provision is a taxation measure bringing to tax directly or indirectly the sales effected outside the State of Bombay. In Abdul Quadar and Co. v. Sales Tax Officer, Hyderabad, 1  interpreting s. 11 2  of, the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act 1952, a provision somewhat similar to, the impugned provision, this Court observed that legislation under Entry 54 of List II of the Constitution  similar to Entry 48 of List 11 of the Government of India Act, 1935,

arguments.claim: Section 12A(4) violates Art.19(1)(f) as it infringes right to hold property by forfeiting amounts without proper enquiry or procedure.

anchor.surface_text: But the question is whether it is violative of Art. 19 1  f  which guarantees the freedom to hold property. Prima facie the appellants are entitled to get the amount ordered to be refunded to them.

arguments.claim: No one can be penalised without proper enquiry; s.12A(4) violates principles of natural justice by providing forfeiture without any procedure, adjudication or opportunity to be heard.

anchor.surface_text: Under our jurisprudence numberone can be penalised without a proper enquiry. Penalising a person without an enquiry is abhorrent to our sense of justice. It is a violation of the principles of natural justice, which we value so much. The impugned provision which provides for the forfeiture of the amount in the hands of the dealers, does number lay down any procedure for ascertaining whether in fact the dealer companycerned bad companylected any amount by way of tax from his purchasers outside the State and if so what that amount is.

arguments.claim: Imposition of penalty is quasi-judicial requiring enquiry; s.12A(4) treats it as administrative without machinery or procedure.

anchor.surface_text: We shall number go into the question whether from the language of the impugned provision it is possible to hold that it is a penal provision. For our present purpose we shall assume it to be so. ... The imposition of a penalty on a person is at least of a quasi-judicial character.

arguments.claim: Power under s.12A(4) is unguided, uncanalised, uncontrolled and arbitrary.

anchor.surface_text: On a reasonable interpretation of the impugned provision, we have numberdoubt that the power companyferred under S. 12A 4  is unguided, uncanalised and uncontrolled. It is an arbitrary power.

arguments.claim: Restrictions under s.12A(4) on Art.19(1)(f) are not reasonable under Art.19(5) as lack both substantive and procedural reasonableness.

anchor.surface_text: As held by this Court in Dr. N.B. Khare v. State of Delhi 1 , whether the restrictions imposed by a. legislative enactment upon a fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 19 1  are reasonable within the meaning of Art. 19 5  would depend as much on the procedural portion of the law as the substantive part of it.

arguments.claim: s.12A(4) upheld as valid (in Ram Gopal case, cited by respondents).

anchor.surface_text: That decision upheld the validity of s. 12A 4 . If that decision lays down the law companyrectly, then the appellants are out of companyrt.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: , such a case also companyes within the scope of s. 12A 4 . Yet that s

arguments.claim: Appellants entitled to refunds as sales protected under Art.286(1)(a), not exigible to tax under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In view of Art. 286 1  a  of the Constitution as it stood at the relevant time, the appellants sales outside the State of Bombay were number exigible to tax.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: exigible as tax under the law. According to the Revenue s. 12A 4  is a penal pr

holdings.text: S. 12A(4) of the Bombay Sales Tax Act 1946 is void, being violative of Art. 19(1)(f) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: As in our judgment that provision is void, the same being violative of Art. 19 1  f  of the Constitution, we have not thought it necessary to examine the other contentions raised in the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provision allows forfeiture without procedure, enquiry or opportunity to be heard, violating right to property; arbitrary and uncontrolled power not a reasonable restriction under Art. 19(5).

holdings.text: The impugned provision violates Art. 19(1)(f) as it infringes the freedom to hold property by providing for forfeiture without proper enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: But the question is whether it is violative of Art. 19 1  f  which guarantees the freedom to hold property. Prima facie the appellants are entitled to get the amount ordered to be refunded to them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessees entitled to refunds; forfeiture only as penalty requires enquiry; provision lacks any procedural safeguards.

holdings.text: The power conferred under S. 12A(4) is unguided, uncanalised, uncontrolled and arbitrary.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No adjudication, machinery or procedure prescribed; treated as administrative despite quasi-judicial nature of penalty.

holdings.text: Restrictions imposed by S. 12A(4) on Art. 19(1)(f) are not reasonable within Art. 19(5).

anchor.surface_text: whether the restrictions imposed by a. legislative enactment upon a fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 19 1  are reasonable within the meaning of Art. 19 5  would depend as much on the procedural portion of the law as the substantive part of it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both substantive and procedural aspects unreasonable; follows Dr. N.B. Khare and State of Madras v. V.G. Rao requiring examination of both.

holdings.text: The decision in Ram Gopal v. Sales Tax Officer upholding S. 12A(4) cannot be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: But we think that the said decision cannot be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contrary to constitutional requirements of procedure and reasonableness under Art. 19.

holdings.text: Appellants' sales outside the State of Bombay were not exigible to tax under the Act in view of Art. 286(1)(a) as it stood at the relevant time.

anchor.surface_text: In view of Art. 286 1  a  of the Constitution as it stood at the relevant time, the appellants sales outside the State of Bombay were not exigible to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of constitutional restriction on state taxation power.

holdings.text: Imposition of penalty is at least of a quasi-judicial character requiring enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: The imposition of a penalty on a person is at least of a quasi-judicial character.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Penalising without enquiry violates natural justice; provision ignores this by lacking procedure.

precedents.citation: Abdul Quadar and Co. v. Sales Tax Officer, Hyderabad, 1 [1964] 6 S.C.R. 867

anchor.surface_text: In Abdul Quadar and Co. v. Sales Tax Officer, Hyderabad, 1  interpreting s. 11 2  of, the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act 1952, a provision somewhat similar to, the impugned provision, this Court observed that legislation under Entry 54 of List II of the Constitution  similar to Entry 48 of List 11 of the Government of India Act, 1935, the entry with which we are companycerned in this case  proceeds on the basis that the amount companycerned is number a tax exigible under the law made under that entry, but even so lays down that though it is number exigible under the law, it shall be paid over to the government merely because some dealers by mistake or otherwise have companylected it as tax hence, it is difficult to see how such a provision can be ancillary or incidental to the companylection of tax legitimately due under a law made under the relevant taxing entry.

precedents.case_name: Abdul Quadar and Co. v. Sales Tax Officer, Hyderabad
precedents.cited_proposition: Legislation under sales tax entry requiring payment of non-exigible tax collected to government is not ancillary or incidental to legitimate tax collection
precedents.cited_holding: it is difficult to see how such a provision can be ancillary or incidental to the collection of tax legitimately due under a law made under the relevant taxing entry

precedents.citation: Ram Gopal v. Sales Tax Officer, Surat and Another 1 [16 S.T.C. 1005]

anchor.surface_text: In support of that companytention reliance was placed on the decision of the Gujarat High Court in Ram Gopal v. Sales Tax Officer, Surat and Another 1 . That decision upheld the validity of s. 12A 4 . If that decision lays down the law companyrectly, then the appellants are out of companyrt. But we think that the said decision cannot be sustained.

precedents.case_name: Ram Gopal v. Sales Tax Officer, Surat
precedents.cited_proposition: Validity of s. 12A(4) as upheld by Gujarat High Court

precedents.citation: Dr. N.B. Khare v. State of Delhi 1 [1950 S.C.R. 519]

anchor.surface_text: As held by this Court in Dr. N.B. Khare v. State of Delhi 1 , whether the restrictions imposed by a. legislative enactment upon a fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 19 1  are reasonable within the meaning of Art. 19 5  would depend as much on the procedural portion of the law as the substantive part of it.

precedents.case_name: Dr. N.B. Khare v. State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: Reasonableness of restrictions on Art. 19(1) rights depends on both procedural and substantive aspects of the law
precedents.cited_holding: whether the restrictions imposed by a legislative enactment upon a fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 19(1) are reasonable within the meaning of Art. 19(5) would depend as much on the procedural portion of the law as the substantive part of it

precedents.citation: State of Madras v. V. G. Rao 1

anchor.surface_text: That view was reiterated by this Court in State of Madras v. V. G. Rao 1 wherein it was observed that in companysidering the reasonableness of laws imposing restrictions on fundamental rights both the substantive and procedural aspects of the impugned law should be examined from the point of view of reasonableness.

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v. V.G. Rao
precedents.cited_proposition: Reasonableness of laws restricting fundamental rights requires examining both substantive and procedural aspects
precedents.cited_holding: in considering the reasonableness of laws imposing restrictions on fundamental rights both the substantive and procedural aspects of the impugned law should be examined from the point of view of reasonableness
